item.title: Семеро их 1933 (1917)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Annotations: pencil; red crayon; blue crayon; blue pen
item.Notes: Printed score and appended corrections. Score published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). Subsequently marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page of the printed score is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. The last seven leaves contain autograph revisions and corrections.
item.Previous_holding_library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
item.altformavail: Also available in Photocopy: SPA_ID 124 Also available in Microfilm: SPA_ID 262 Also available in Digital: SPA_ID 361

item.title: [Untitled]1925

Parts of the third movement (Dance - Allegro energico) are sketched in pencil. End dated August 4, 1925. Final sheet contains ending of Matelote movement of Trapèze (beginning present in BN#23494). item.title: [Untitled]1928-1931
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Notes: Final version for engraving. Prepared for publication under plate numbers R.M.V. 529 - R.M.V. 534. Pagination and line splits (as well as a few very minor annotations) marked in pencil. Originally the titles were marked with numbers, but subsequently the movement numbers have been crossed out. A note in pencil in upper left margin on first page reads "Gravez en format ordinaire. Pagination separée" [Engrave in ordinary format. Separate pagination] and a few of the movements have notes that ask for space to be left for title and dedication. Two of the movements have dedications: The Scherzino to Nicolas Orloff and the Scherzo to Vladimir Horowitz. Folio 14r contains a sketch for another piece. Dates indicated are: I. 1931 (1928) II. [Date erased] III. [No date] IV. 1920 (1931) V. 1930 (1931) VI. 1909(1931)

item.Notes: Piano reduction of the ballet score. Appears to be the final version before engraving for the rehearsal score, to be published under plate number R.M.V 520 (Pages are marked up in pencil for engraving, although there is no red stamp indicating that this was indeed engraved). Movements do not appear in the same order as in the final version. Pencil markings indicate the new order of movements. Front page dated 1930. End dated February 12, 1931; Paris. On the first page, the working title "Un Dimanche soir" has been crossed out. Then the title "Au Borysthène" has been written in blue ink. Finally the word "Au" has been crossed out in pencil and corrected to "Sur le."

item.title: Le Joueur; Игрокъ, Der Spieler1916 (1927)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil. red crayon; blue crayon; purple crayon
item.Notes: Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.
item.Previous_holding_library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
item.altformavail: Also available in Photocopy: SPA_ID 131 Also available in Microfilm: SPA_ID 232 Also available in Digital: SPA_ID 333

item.title: Музыкальное письмо Б.С. Захарову от С.С. Прокофьева в Вену из Петербурга1952(1913)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Standard_title: Musical letter from Prokofiev to Boris Zakharov
item.Notes: First page is an explanation of the themes used in the letter. This item contains one full version of the work and one fragmentary one. The following note appears at the end of the first version: "Письмо написано и послано в октябре-ноябре 1913 года. Восстановлено по памяти через 38 лет, т.е.. в 1952 году" [Letter written and sent in October-November 1913. Recovered from memory after 38 years, i.e in. 1952]

item.title: Семеро их 1933 (1917)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Notes: After a title page, the first seven pages contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Pages 21 and 26 of the original present in duplicate.
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Notes: Second version of opera. Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. item.title: Соната для виолончели соло1973 (1952)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
Blok, V. (Vladimir), 1932-1996
item.Notes: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

item.title: [Untitled]1925
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Notes: First leaf contains a sketch of the beginning and end of the first movement (Moderato). The back of the next folio contains a partial transposition one tone down of a portion of the movement. The opening theme of the second movement (Nocturne - Larghetto) is sketched several times. Parts of the third movement (Dance - Allegro energico) are sketched in pencil. End dated August 4, 1925. Contains ending of Matelote movement of Trapèze (beginning present in item 15). item.title: Семеро их 1933 (1917)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Notes: After a title page, the first seven slides contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. (Corrections rendered out of order.)
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

item.title: Соната для виолончели соло1973 (1952)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
Blok, V. (Vladimir), 1932-1996
item.Notes: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London
item.altformavail: Also available in Photocopy: SPA_ID 137

item.Notes: Second version of the opera. Final copy for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

item.title: Музыкальное письмо Б.С. Захарову от С.С. Прокофьева в Вену из Петербурга1913
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Standard_title: Musical letter from Prokofiev to Boris Zakharov
item.Notes: First page is an explanation of the themes used in the letter. Contains one full version and one fragmentary. The first one appears more like a draft than the second (repeats not written out), but the second is unfinished. The following note appears at the end of the first version: "Письмо написано и послано в октябре-ноябре 1913 года. Восстановлено по памяти через 38 лет, т.е.. в 1952 году." [Letter written and sent in October-November 1913. Recovered from memory after 38 years, i.e in. 1952]
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

item.Standard_title: Five Poems of K. Balmont; No. 1 - Заклинанiе Воды и Огня (Incantation of Water and Fire)
item.Notes: First song - "Incantation of Water and Fire" ("Заклинанiе Воды и Огня"). The dedication originally read "A Linette Codina," but the name has been changed to Lina Llubera (Changed reflects a switch from her real name to her pseudonym). French translation by Lina Llubera and Serge Prokofiev, German text by Vera Miller, English text by Olga Mojaysky. Prepared for publication under plate number A. 10338 G.

item.title: Семеро их 1933 (1917)
item.Creator: Prokofiev, Sergey, 1891 1953
item.Notes: After a title page, the first seven pages contain autograph revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French transaltion by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. Corrections rendered out of order.
item.Previous_holding_library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London
